content: In the shadow of Stenograd’s failing Behavioral Compliance Index, Oksana Lintz, wary of spreading chaos and broken systems, quietly warns trusted community leaders to brace for self-rule. As the government’s grip loosens, neighborhoods swiftly seize control of resources and services, forming a vibrant Peoples’ Congress that sidelines the powerless Council and empowers former outcasts to lead. Yet as the Congress flourishes, cracks soon appear—some opportunists turn corrupt, hoarding what they once lacked. The desperate Council tries to win back influence by dangling lost privileges, but most citizens refuse, leaving the city in a tense standoff between hopeful reform and the old order’s shadow, as a new vision of governance begins to take root.
